PrimaryPrelims.Title: A Bill [AS AMENDED ON REPORT] To

Para.Text: Make provision for establishing and maintaining a register of persons carrying on the business of consultant lobbying and to require those persons to be entered in the register; to make provision about expenditure and donations for political purposes; to make provision about the Electoral Commission’s functions with respect to compliance with requirements imposed by or by virtue of enactments; to make provision relating to a trade union’s duty to maintain a register of members under section 24 of the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992; and for connected purposes.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P1group.Title: Prohibition on consultant lobbying unless registered

P2para.Text: A person must not carry on the business of consultant lobbying unless the person is entered in the register of consultant lobbyists.
Sections 3 to 7 make provision about the keeping and publication of the register.
For the purposes of this Part, a person carries on the business of consultant lobbying if—

P3para.Text: in the course of a business and in return for payment, the person makes communications within subsection (3) on behalf of another person or persons,
the person is registered under the Value Added Tax Act 1994, and
none of the exceptions in Part 1 of Schedule 1 applies.

P2para.Text: Part 2 of that Schedule makes provision about the meaning, for the purposes of this Part of this Act, of terms used in subsection (1).
The communications within this subsection are oral or written communications made personally to a Minister of the Crown, permanent secretary or special adviser relating to—

P3para.Text: the development, adoption or modification of any proposal of the government to make or amend primary or subordinate legislation;
the development, adoption or modification of any other policy of the government;
the making, giving or issuing by the government of, or the taking of any other steps by the government in relation to,—

P4para.Text: any contract or other agreement,
any grant or other financial assistance, or
any licence or other authorisation; or

P3para.Text: the exercise of any other function of the government.

P2para.Text: It does not matter whether the person to whom the communication is made, or the person making it, or both, are outside the United Kingdom when the communication is made.
In this section—

Para.Text: “the government” means Her Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom;
“Minister of the Crown” means the holder of an office in the government, and includes the Treasury;
“permanent secretary” means a person serving the government in—
the position of permanent secretary or second permanent secretary in the civil service of the State, or
a position listed in Part 3 of Schedule 1 (positions equivalent to those mentioned in paragraph (a)).

P2para.Text: There is to be a Registrar of Consultant Lobbyists.
Schedule 2 makes provision about the Registrar.
The Registrar must keep and publish a register of consultant lobbyists.
The entry for each registered person must include—

P3para.Text: in the case of a company—

P4para.Text: its name, its registered number and the address of its registered office, and
the names of its directors and of any secretary and any shadow directors;

P3para.Text: in the case of a partnership (including a limited liability partnership), the names of the partners and the address of its main office or place of business;
in the case of an individual, the individual’s name and the address of the individual’s main place of business (or, if there is no such place, the individual’s residence);
in the case of any other person (including persons outside the United Kingdom), the equivalent information as specified in regulations;
any name or names, not included under paragraphs (a) to (d), under which the person carries on business as a consultant lobbyist;
such other information regarding the identity of the person as may be determined by the Registrar;
a statement of—

P4para.Text: whether there is in place an undertaking by the person to comply with a relevant code of conduct, and
if so, where a copy of the code may be inspected;

P3para.Text: such other information as may be specified in regulations.

P2para.Text: Each entry must also include—

P3para.Text: for each quarter in which the registered person has been entered in the register, the person’s client information (see section 5(3)) or the statement under section 5(5), and
if the person received payment in the pre-registration quarter to engage in lobbying, the name of the person or persons on whose behalf the lobbying was or is to be done.

P2para.Text: The pre-registration quarter is the period of 3 months ending on the date on which the person applied to be entered in the register.
Regulations may make further provision in connection with the register; and in particular may—

P3para.Text: specify other information about the persons mentioned in subsection (3)(b) which must be included in the register;
make provision about applications to be entered in the register, including the form and content of those applications.

P2para.Text: In this section—

P3para.Text: any expression which is used in subsection (2)(a) and in the Companies Acts has the meaning which it has in those Acts (see, in particular, Schedule 8 to the Companies Act 2006);

a “relevant code of conduct” (in subsection (2)(g)) is a code of conduct which governs the carrying on of the business of consultant lobbying (whether or not it also governs other activities) and is open to inspection by members of the public.

P1group.Title: Notification of client information and changes

P2para.Text: A registered person must submit an information return to the Registrar for each quarter.
The information return for a quarter must contain—

P3para.Text: either the client information for that quarter or a statement under subsection (5), and
details of any change in that quarter in the particulars included in the register under section 4(2).

P2para.Text: The client information for a quarter is—

P3para.Text: if the registered person engaged in lobbying in the quarter in return for payment (whether or not the payment has been received), the name of the person or persons on whose behalf the lobbying was done, and

if the registered person received payment in the quarter to engage in lobbying (whether or not the lobbying has been done), the name of the person or persons on whose behalf the lobbying is or was to be done.

P2para.Text: Regulations may specify other information about the persons mentioned in subsection (3) which must be included in an information return.
A statement under this subsection is a statement that, in the quarter in question, the registered person neither engaged in lobbying in return for payment nor received payment to engage in lobbying.
The information return for a quarter must be submitted before the end of the period of 2 weeks beginning immediately after the end of the quarter.
The Registrar must keep the register up to date.
In particular, the Registrar must comply with subsections (3) and (4).

Where a person applies, in accordance with regulations, to be entered in the register, the Registrar must register the person before the end of the period of 4 working days beginning with the day after the day on which the application is received.
The Registrar must update the register to include any information or change which is notified in an information return.
The Registrar must comply with subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: if the return is received before the end of the period specified in section 5(6), before the end of the period of 4 working days beginning with the day after the day on which the return is received, or
if the return is received after the end of that period, before the end of the period of 8 working days beginning with the day after the day on which the return is received.

P2para.Text: If the Registrar has reasonable grounds for believing that a registered person is not (or is no longer) a consultant lobbyist, the Registrar may decide that—

P3para.Text: the person’s entry should include a statement to that effect, or
the person’s entry should be removed from the register.

P2para.Text: In this section “working day” means any day other than—

P3para.Text: a Saturday or Sunday, or
a day which is a bank holiday under the Banking and Financial Dealings Act 1971 in any part of the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: The Registrar must publish the register as kept in accordance with section 6.
The Registrar may publish such entries, or parts of entries, as the Registrar considers appropriate in respect of persons who were, but are no longer, entered in the register.
Publication under this section is to be—

P3para.Text: on a website, and
in such other form or forms as the Registrar considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The Registrar must monitor compliance with the obligations imposed by or under this Part.

In connection with the duty under section 8, the Registrar may serve a notice (an “information notice”) on a person mentioned in subsection (2) requiring the person to supply information specified in the notice.
The persons are—

P3para.Text: any registered person;
any person who is not entered in the register but whom the Registrar has reasonable grounds for believing to be a consultant lobbyist.

P2para.Text: Regulations may specify descriptions of information which the Registrar may not require a person to supply under this section.
An information notice must—

P3para.Text: specify the form in which the information must be supplied,
specify the date by which the information must be supplied, and
contain particulars of the right to appeal under section 11.

P2para.Text: The date specified under subsection (4)(b) must not be before the end of the period within which an appeal under section 11 can be brought.
Section 10 sets out limitations on—

P3para.Text: what information is required to be supplied under a notice, and
how information which is supplied may be used.

P2para.Text: Where an information notice has been served on a person, the Registrar may cancel it by serving written notice to that effect on the person.

P1group.Title: Limitations on duty to supply information and use of information supplied

P2para.Text: An information notice does not require a person to supply information if—

P3para.Text: doing so would disclose evidence of the commission of an offence, other than an offence excluded by subsection (2), and
the disclosure would expose the person to proceedings for that offence.

P2para.Text: The following offences are excluded from subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: an offence under this Part;
an offence under section 5 of the Perjury Act 1911 (false statements made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under section 44 of the Criminal Law (Consolidation) (Scotland) Act 1995 (false statements made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under Article 10 of the Perjury (Northern Ireland) Order 1979 (S.I.1979/1714 (N.I.19)) (false statutory declarations etc).

P2para.Text: Any relevant statement made by a person (“P”) in response to a requirement in an information notice may not be used in evidence against P on a prosecution for an offence under this Part (except section 12(4)) unless the conditions in subsection (4) are met.
The conditions are that in the proceedings—

P3para.Text: in giving evidence P provides information inconsistent with the relevant statement, and
evidence relating to the statement is adduced, or a question relating to it is asked, by P or on P’s behalf.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3) “relevant statement”, in relation to a requirement in an information notice, means—

P3para.Text: an oral statement, or
a written statement made for the purposes of the requirement.

P1group.Title: Right to appeal against information notice

P2para.Text: A person on whom an information notice has been served may appeal to the Tribunal against the notice.
If an appeal is brought under this section, the person is not required to supply the information until the date on which the appeal is finally determined or withdrawn.
Regulations may make provision for and in connection with the determination of appeals under this section.
If a person carries on the business of consultant lobbying in breach of section 1(1) (lobbying whilst unregistered), an offence is committed by—

P3para.Text: the person, and
any individual who, not being entered in the register, engages in lobbying in the course of that business.

P2para.Text: It is an offence for a registered person to engage in lobbying if—

P3para.Text: the person’s entry in the register is inaccurate or incomplete in a material particular, and

the person has failed, when required to submit an information return under section 5, to provide sufficient information in or accompanying the return to enable the inaccuracy or omission to be rectified.

P2para.Text: Where a person is required to submit an information return under section 5, it is an offence for the person—

P3para.Text: to fail to do so within the period specified in section 5(6), or
to provide information which is inaccurate or incomplete in a material particular.

P2para.Text: Where an information notice has been served on a person, it is an offence for the person—

P3para.Text: to fail to supply the required information on or before the date by which the person is required to do so, or
to provide information which is inaccurate or incomplete in a material particular.

P2para.Text: It is a defence for a person charged under any of subsections (1) to (4) to show that the person exercised all due diligence to avoid committing the offence.
A person is taken to have shown the fact mentioned in subsection (5) if—

P3para.Text: sufficient evidence of the fact is adduced to raise an issue with respect to it, and
the contrary is not proved beyond reasonable doubt.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under any of subsections (1) to (4) is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum;
on summary conviction in England and Wales, or on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

P2para.Text: In the case of a summary conviction in England and Wales for an offence committed before the coming into force of section 85 of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012, the fine under subsection (7) must not exceed the statutory maximum.
Proceedings for an offence under this Part may be instituted—

P3para.Text: in England and Wales, only by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions;
in Northern Ireland, only by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: Where an offence under this Part is committed by a body corporate and is proved—

P3para.Text: to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a director, manager, secretary or other similar officer, or
to be attributable to any neglect on the part of any such individual,

P2para.Text: the individual as well as the body corporate is guilty of the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

Where the affairs of a body corporate are managed by its members, subsection (1) applies in relation to the acts and omissions of a member in connection with that management as if the member were a director of the body corporate.
Where an offence under this Part is committed by a partnership constituted under the law of Scotland and is proved—

P3para.Text: to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a partner, or
to be attributable to any neglect on the part of any such individual,

P2para.Text: the individual as well as the partnership is guilty of the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

The Registrar may impose a civil penalty on a person (in accordance with sections 15 to 18) if the Registrar is satisfied that the person’s conduct amounts to an offence under any of subsections (1) to (4) of section 12.
For this purpose—

P3para.Text: section 12(5) (defence of due diligence) is to be ignored, and
a person’s conduct includes a failure to act.

P1group.Title: Notice of intention to impose civil penalty

P2para.Text: Before imposing a civil penalty on a person, the Registrar must serve on that person a notice stating that the Registrar proposes to impose the penalty.
The notice must—

P3para.Text: set out the conduct on which the proposal to impose the penalty is based,
set out the reasons why the Registrar is satisfied that the person has engaged in that conduct,
state the amount of the proposed penalty, and
inform the person that the person may, within a period specified in the notice, make written representations in relation to the proposal.

P2para.Text: The Registrar must not impose the penalty before the end of the period specified under subsection (2)(d).
The Registrar must consider any written representations received before the end of that period.
If the Registrar decides to impose a civil penalty, the Registrar must serve on the person a notice to that effect (a “penalty notice”).
The notice must—

P3para.Text: set out the conduct on which the decision to impose the penalty is based,
set out the reasons why the Registrar is satisfied that the person has engaged in that conduct,
state the amount of the penalty,
specify the period within which and the form in which the penalty must be paid, and
contain particulars of the right to appeal under section 17.

P2para.Text: The amount specified in a penalty notice must not exceed £7500.
Regulations may amend subsection (3) by substituting a different maximum figure.
The period specified under subsection (2)(d) must not end before the end of the period within which an appeal under section 17 can be brought.
The person must pay the amount before the end of that period (but this is subject to section 17(2)).
Where a penalty notice has been served on a person, the Registrar may vary or cancel it by serving written notice to that effect on the person.

P1group.Title: Right to appeal against imposition of civil penalty

P2para.Text: A person on whom a penalty notice has been served may appeal to the Tribunal against—

P3para.Text: the decision to impose the penalty;
if the penalty notice has been varied, the decision to vary it;
the amount of the penalty.

P2para.Text: If an appeal is brought under this section, the person is not required to pay the penalty until the date on which the appeal is finally determined or withdrawn.
Regulations may make provision for and in connection with the determination of appeals under this section.
The Registrar may not impose a civil penalty on a person in respect of any conduct—

P3para.Text: at any time after criminal proceedings for an offence under this Part have been instituted against the person in respect of that conduct and before those proceedings have been concluded, or
after the person has been convicted of an offence under this Part in respect of that conduct.

P2para.Text: If the Registrar has imposed a civil penalty on a person in respect of any conduct, the person may not be convicted of an offence under this Part in respect of that conduct.
An amount payable to the Registrar as a civil penalty may be recovered by the Registrar as a debt.
In proceedings for the enforcement of a civil penalty no question may be raised as to—

P3para.Text: liability to the imposition of the penalty, or
the amount of the penalty.

P2para.Text: The Registrar must pay into the Consolidated Fund any sums received by virtue of a penalty notice.
Regulations may make further provision about civil penalties; and in particular may—

P3para.Text: specify circumstances in which a penalty may not be imposed;
specify steps that the Registrar must take before imposing a penalty;
set a minimum for the period which must be specified under section 15(2)(d) or 16(2)(d);
require other matters to be specified in a notice under either of those sections;
specify a maximum period that may elapse between the service of a notice under section 15 and the service of a penalty notice under section 16;
provide for the reviewing of a decision to impose a penalty;
make provision about the variation or cancellation under section 16(7) of penalty notices;
impose duties on the Registrar about the keeping of accounts and other records in relation to penalties;
allow for the charging of interest, or an additional penalty, if a penalty is paid late.

P2para.Text: The Registrar may give guidance about how the Registrar proposes to exercise the functions under this Part.
The Registrar may do so, in particular, by publishing guidance—

P3para.Text: as to cases which the Registrar would, or would not, regard as falling within any of the exceptions in Part 1 of Schedule 1;
otherwise as to the circumstances in which the Registrar would, or would not, consider that a person is carrying on the business of consultant lobbying;
as to the circumstances in which the Registrar would—

P4para.Text: include in the register a statement under section 6(6)(a), or
remove a person’s entry from the register;

P3para.Text: as to the circumstances in which the Registrar would consider it appropriate to impose a civil penalty;
about how the amount of a civil penalty will be determined.

P2para.Text: The Registrar may publish—

P3para.Text: revisions to any guidance published under this section;
replacement guidance.

P2para.Text: Publication under this section is to be—

P3para.Text: on a website, and
in such other form or forms as the Registrar considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The Registrar may impose charges for or in connection with the making, updating and maintenance of entries in the register.
The charges are to be determined by or in accordance with regulations.
In making the regulations, the Minister must seek to ensure that the total paid to the Registrar in charges is sufficient to offset the total of the costs incurred
by the Registrar in exercising the functions under this Part (whether or not those costs are directly connected with the keeping of the register).
If a charge imposed for making an application or a return to the Registrar is not paid, the Registrar may treat the application or return as not having been made.
The Registrar must pay into the Consolidated Fund any sums received in respect of charges under this section.
Regulations may make such provision as the Minister considers appropriate for the purposes of carrying into effect any provision of this Part.
Regulations under subsection (1) may in particular make provision (or further provision) about—

P3para.Text: the date from which an entry in the register is to take effect;
the form and content of information returns under section 5;
the exercise of the Registrar’s powers under section 6(6);
the removal of entries in other circumstances;
the minimum period between the date on which an information notice is served and the date which must be specified under section 9(4)(b);
other matters which must be specified in an information notice;
the cancellation of notices under section 9(7).

P2para.Text: Regulations under subsection (1) may make provision permitting or requiring the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs to supply to the Registrar, on request, such information regarding any person who is, or is required to be, registered under the Value Added Tax Act 1994 as is specified in the regulations.
Any reference in this Part to regulations is to regulations made by the Minister.

Regulations under this Part may make such consequential, supplementary, incidental or transitional provision as the Minister considers appropriate, including provision amending or modifying the provisions of this Part.
Regulations under this Part may make different provision for different purposes or cases.
Regulations under this Part are to be made by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing any of the following regulations may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament—

P3para.Text: regulations under section 4(5)(a) or 5(4);
the first regulations to be made under each of sections 11(3) and 17(3);
regulations under this Part which amend or modify the provisions of this Part.

P2para.Text: Any other statutory instrument containing regulations under this Part is to be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
In this Part—

Para.Text: “consultant lobbyist” means a person who carries on the business of consultant lobbying;
“employee” means an individual who works under a contract of employment;
to “engage in lobbying” means to make a communication within section 2(3) on behalf of another person or persons;
“information notice” means a notice under section 9;
“the Minister” means the Secretary of State or the Lord President of the Council;
“payment”, “in return for payment” and references to receiving payment are to be read in accordance with paragraphs 5 to 7 of Schedule 1;
“penalty notice” means a notice under section 16;
“quarter” means each period of three months beginning with 1 January, 1 April, 1 July or 1 October;
“registered person” means a person entered in the register of consultant lobbyists;
“the Tribunal” means—
the First-tier Tribunal, or
in any case where it is determined by or under Tribunal Procedure Rules that the appeal is to be heard by the Upper Tribunal, that Tribunal.

P2para.Text: Where the Registrar is required or permitted to serve a notice on a person, this is to be effected—

P3para.Text: if the person is a registered company (within the meaning of the Companies Act 2006), by sending it by post to the company’s registered office;
if the person is an individual, by delivering it in person, by sending it by post to the individual’s last known place of residence or business, or by leaving it at that place;
in any other case, by sending it by post to the last known main address of that person;

P2para.Text: (but this does not prevent the Registrar from sending additional copies of the notice by whatever means the Registrar considers appropriate).
Section 85 of the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000 (controlled expenditure by third parties) is amended in accordance with subsections (2) to (6).
In subsection (2), for the words from “in connection with” to the end substitute “where—

P3para.Text: the expenses fall within Part 1 of Schedule 8A, and
the expenditure can reasonably be regarded as intended to promote or procure electoral success at any relevant election for—

P4para.Text: one or more particular registered parties,
one or more registered parties who advocate (or do not advocate) particular policies or who otherwise fall within a particular category of such parties, or
candidates who hold (or do not hold) particular opinions or who advocate (or do not advocate) particular policies or who otherwise fall within a particular category of candidates.

P2para.Text: Omit subsection (3).
In subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: in the opening words, for “(3)” substitute “(2)(b)”;
in paragraph (b)—

P4para.Text: for “paragraph (a) or (as the case may be) paragraph (b) of that subsection” substitute “that provision”;
omit “or (as the case may be) by prejudicing the standing with the electorate of other parties or candidates”;
at the end insert “and”;

P3para.Text: for the words after that paragraph substitute—
a course of conduct may constitute the doing of one of those things even though it does not involve any express mention being made of the name of any party or candidate.

P2para.Text: After subsection (4) insert—

In determining whether expenditure can reasonably be regarded as intended to promote or procure electoral success as mentioned in subsection (2)(b), it is immaterial that it can reasonably be regarded as intended to achieve any other purpose as well.
In subsection (9), for “subsection (3)” substitute “that subsection”.
In section 87 of that Act (expenditure by third parties which is not controlled expenditure)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), omit paragraph (a) and the “or” at the end of it;
omit subsection (2).

P2para.Text: Section 94 of that Act (limits on controlled expenditure by third parties) is amended in accordance with subsections (9) and (10).
After subsection (4) insert—
It is a defence for any person or third party charged with an offence under subsection (2) or (4) to show—

P3para.Text: that any code of practice for the time being issued under paragraph 2 of Schedule 8A was complied with in determining whether any expenditure is controlled expenditure for the purposes of this Part, and
that the person or third party’s acts or omissions would not have amounted to an offence on the basis of the controlled expenditure as determined in accordance with the code.

P2para.Text: In subsection (6)(b)—

P3para.Text: for “in connection with the production or publication of election material which” substitute “and the expenditure”;
for “85(3)” substitute “85(2)(b)”.

P2para.Text: In section 143 of that Act (details to appear on election material)—

P3para.Text: in subsections (2A) and (2B)—

P4para.Text: for “, procuring or enhancing” substitute “or procuring”;
omit “or standing”;

P3para.Text: in subsection (11), for the definition of “election material” substitute—

Para.Text: “election material” has the meaning given by section 143A;

P2para.Text: After section 143 of that Act insert—
“Election material” means material which can reasonably be regarded as intended to promote or procure electoral success at any relevant election for—

P3para.Text: one or more particular registered parties,
one or more registered parties who advocate (or do not advocate) particular policies or who otherwise fall within a particular category of such parties, or
candidates who hold (or do not hold) particular opinions or who advocate (or do not advocate) particular policies or who otherwise fall within a particular category of candidates.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: the reference to electoral success at any relevant election is a reference—

P4para.Text: in relation to a registered party, to the return at any such election of candidates standing in the name of the party or included in a list of candidates submitted by the party in connection with the election, and
in relation to candidates, to their return at any such election,

P3para.Text: the reference to doing any of the things mentioned in that subsection includes doing so by prejudicing the electoral prospects at the election of other parties or candidates, and
a course of conduct may constitute the doing of one of those things even though it does not involve any express mention being made of the name of any party or candidate.

P2para.Text: In determining whether material can reasonably be regarded as intended to promote or procure electoral success as mentioned in subsection (1), it is immaterial that it can reasonably be regarded as intended to achieve any other purpose as well.
In this section—

Para.Text: “candidate” includes a future candidate, whether identifiable or not;
“relevant election” has the same meaning as in Part 2 (see section 22(5)).

P3para.Text: paragraph 5 of Schedule 8A,

P1group.Title: Arrangements between third parties notified to the Electoral Commission

P2para.Text: Part 6 of the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000 (controls relating to third party national election campaigns) is amended as follows.
In section 94 (limits on controlled expenditure by third parties)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (3) insert—

P2para.Text: For provision requiring certain controlled expenditure to be disregarded in determining for the purposes of subsection (3)(a) whether a limit is exceeded, see section 94A(5) (arrangements between third parties notified to the Commission).

P3para.Text: in subsection (4), for “such a case” substitute “the case mentioned in subsection (3)”;
in subsection (5A)—

P4para.Text: after “Subsections (3) to (5)” insert “and section 94A”;
for “those subsections” substitute “those provisions”;

P3para.Text: in subsections (8) and (10), after “the purposes of this section” insert “, section 94A”;
in subsection (11)(a), after “this section” insert “and section 94A”.

P2para.Text: After section 94 insert—

P1group.Title: Arrangements between third parties notified to the Commission

P2para.Text: A recognised third party (“a lead campaigner”) may, at any time before the end of a regulated period, send a notice to the Commission—

P3para.Text: stating that the lead campaigner is party to an arrangement of the kind mentioned in section 94(6), and
identifying one or more third parties that—

P4para.Text: are parties to the arrangement, and
have agreed to be minor campaigners in relation to the arrangement.

P2para.Text: A notice under subsection (1)—

Pblock.Title: Financial limits on targeted controlled expenditure

P2para.Text: Sections 94C to 94G impose limits on, and make other provision relating to, controlled expenditure incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party where the expenditure is targeted at a particular registered party.
Section 94C defines when controlled expenditure is regarded as targeted at a particular registered party, specifies the limits and specifies the periods over which the limits operate.

Section 94D makes provision about the consequences where controlled expenditure targeted at a registered party is incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party in excess of a limit without authorisation from the registered party.

Section 94E makes provision about the consequences where controlled expenditure targeted at a registered party is incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party in excess of a limit with authorisation from the registered party.

Section 94F makes provision about how a registered party may give or withdraw authorisation (including provision enabling the registered party to specify a cap on the amount of expenditure authorised).
Section 94G makes provision about the meaning of references to expenditure that “exceeds” a targeted expenditure limit or cap.
Controlled expenditure is “targeted” at a particular registered party if it can reasonably be regarded as—

P3para.Text: intended to benefit that party or any of its candidates, and
not intended to benefit any other registered party or any of its candidates.

P2para.Text: A limit (a “targeted expenditure limit”) applies to controlled expenditure that—

P3para.Text: is incurred during a qualifying regulated period in England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland, and
is targeted at a particular registered party.

P2para.Text: A “qualifying regulated period” is a period in relation to which limits are imposed by paragraph 3(2), 9(3) or (5), 10(3) or 11(3) of Schedule 10 (periods involving parliamentary general elections).
The targeted expenditure limit applying to controlled expenditure incurred during a qualifying regulated period in a part of the United Kingdom is—

P3para.Text: for the period in relation to which limits are imposed by paragraph 3(2) of Schedule 10, 0.2% of the maximum campaign expenditure limit in that part of the United Kingdom, and
for any other qualifying regulated period, the relevant proportion of the limit determined in accordance with paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: In subsection (4)(a) “maximum campaign expenditure limit” has the meaning given by section 94(10).
In subsection (4)(b) “the relevant proportion” means—

Para.Text: where—
A is the number of days in the period mentioned in subsection (4)(b);
B is the number of days in the period mentioned in subsection (4)(a).

P2para.Text: This section applies for the purposes of sections 94D to 94G.

P1group.Title: Unauthorised expenditure in excess of targeted expenditure limit

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: controlled expenditure which is targeted at a particular registered party (“the registered party”) is incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party (“the third party”),
the expenditure exceeds a targeted expenditure limit (to any extent), and
at the time the expenditure is incurred—

P4para.Text: the third party is not authorised by the registered party to incur expenditure targeted at it, or
the third party is so authorised, but the expenditure exceeds a cap specified in the authorisation (to any extent).

P2para.Text: If the third party is not an individual—

P3para.Text: the responsible person is guilty of an offence if the person authorised the expenditure to be incurred by or on behalf of the third party and the person knew or ought reasonably to have known that the expenditure would be incurred in excess of the targeted expenditure limit, and
the third party is also guilty of an offence.

P2para.Text: If the third party is an individual, the third party is guilty of an offence if the third party knew or ought reasonably to have known that the expenditure would be incurred in excess of the targeted expenditure limit.

P1group.Title: Authorised expenditure in excess of targeted expenditure limit

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: controlled expenditure which is targeted at a particular registered party (“the registered party”) is incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party (“the third party”),
the expenditure exceeds a targeted expenditure limit (to any extent),
at the time the expenditure is incurred the third party is authorised by the registered party to incur expenditure targeted at it, and
if the registered party specified a cap in the authorisation, the expenditure, or any part of it, does not exceed the cap.

P2para.Text: The authorised amount is treated for the purposes of section 79(2) (limits on campaign expenditure) as if—

P3para.Text: it were campaign expenditure within the meaning of Part 5, and
it was incurred by the registered party at the same time as the controlled expenditure mentioned in subsection (1)(a) was in fact incurred by or on behalf of the third party.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this section, “the authorised amount” is the amount of the controlled expenditure incurred as mentioned in subsection (1)(a) less—

P3para.Text: such amount, if any, of that expenditure as does not exceed the targeted expenditure limit, and
such amount, if any, of that expenditure as exceeds a cap specified by the registered party in its authorisation of the third party.

P2para.Text: In determining whether, by virtue of subsection (2), the incurring of controlled expenditure by or on behalf of the third party constitutes an offence under section 79(2) by the treasurer or any deputy treasurer of the registered party, section 79(2)(a)(i) is treated as if the reference in that provision to the authorisation of the expenditure were to the signing of the authorisation under section 94F.
The treasurer or a deputy treasurer of the registered party must make a declaration of—

P3para.Text: the amount of the controlled expenditure incurred as mentioned in subsection (1)(a), and
the authorised amount.

P2para.Text: A person commits an offence if the person knowingly or recklessly makes a false declaration under subsection (5).
A registered party may authorise a recognised third party to incur controlled expenditure in England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland that is targeted at the registered party.
An authorisation—

P3para.Text: must be in writing,
must be signed by a relevant officer,
must specify the part of the United Kingdom to which it relates, and
may specify a cap on the amount of expenditure authorised.

P2para.Text: An authorisation is of no effect until a copy of it has been given to the Commission by the registered party.
The Commission must, as soon as is reasonably practicable after receiving a copy of an authorisation, enter in the register maintained under section 89 (register of notifications)—

P3para.Text: the fact that the registered party has given the authorisation, and
the information specified in it.

P2para.Text: A registered party may at any time withdraw an authorisation already given.
A withdrawal of an authorisation—

P3para.Text: must be in writing, and
must be signed by a relevant officer.

P2para.Text: A withdrawal of an authorisation is of no effect until a copy of it has been given to the Commission by the registered party.
The Commission must, as soon as is reasonably practicable after receiving a copy of a withdrawal of an authorisation, update the register maintained under section 89.
For the purposes of this section “relevant officer”, in relation to a registered party, means—

P3para.Text: the treasurer of the party, or
a deputy treasurer of the party.

P1group.Title: Expenditure that “exceeds” a targeted expenditure limit or cap

P2para.Text: Controlled expenditure incurred by or on behalf of a recognised third party during a qualifying regulated period in any part of the United Kingdom that is targeted at a particular registered party “exceeds”—

P3para.Text: a targeted expenditure limit, or
a cap specified by the registered party in its authorisation of the third party,

P2para.Text: if and to the extent that the relevant cumulative total is in excess of that limit or cap.
For this purpose “the relevant cumulative total” is the total of—

P3para.Text: the controlled expenditure incurred as mentioned in subsection (1), and

the total of any controlled expenditure targeted at the same registered party which has already been incurred by or on behalf of the third party during the qualifying regulated period in that part of the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Reporting of donations to recognised third parties

P2para.Text: The Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000 is amended in accordance with subsections (2) to (8).
After section 95 (control of donations to recognised third parties) insert—

P1group.Title: Quarterly and weekly reports of donations to recognised third parties

P2para.Text: The responsible person in relation to a recognised third party must, in respect of each reporting period that falls within a pre-dissolution period, prepare a report about reportable donations (“a quarterly report”).
The reporting periods are—

P3para.Text: the period of 3 months beginning with the first day of the pre-dissolution period,
each succeeding period of 3 months falling within the pre-dissolution period, and
any final period of less than 3 months falling within that period.

P2para.Text: A “pre-dissolution period” means a period—

P3para.Text: beginning with the first day of a qualifying regulated period, and
ending with the day before the day (or the last day) during that qualifying regulated period on which Parliament is dissolved.

P2para.Text: A “qualifying regulated period” is a period in relation to which any limit is imposed by paragraph 3, 9, 10 or 11 of Schedule 10 (periods involving parliamentary general elections) other than a period
including the date of the poll for an early parliamentary general election.
An “early parliamentary general election” is a parliamentary general election the date of the poll for which is appointed under section 2(7) of the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011.
A quarterly report must comply with the requirements of Schedule 11A.
A “reportable donation” means a relevant donation (within the meaning of Schedule 11) which—

P3para.Text: is received by the recognised third party in respect of the relevant election or elections the poll or polls for which take place during the qualifying regulated period, and
is accepted, or is dealt with in accordance with section 56(2) (as applied by paragraph 7 of Schedule 11), by the recognised third party during the reporting period.

P2para.Text: A quarterly report must be delivered to the Commission by the responsible person within the period of 30 days beginning with the end of the reporting period to which it relates.
The report must be accompanied by a declaration signed by the responsible person stating that, to the best of that person’s knowledge and belief—

P3para.Text: all reportable donations (if any) recorded in the report as having been accepted by the recognised third party are from permissible donors, and
there are no reportable donations which are required to be recorded in the report in accordance with Schedule 11A which are not so recorded.

P2para.Text: This section does not require the preparation of a quarterly report in respect of a reporting period if no reportable donations are accepted, or dealt with, as described in subsection (7)(b), by the recognised third party during that period.
This section does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: a recognised third party which is a registered party other than a minor party, or
a recognised Gibraltar third party.

P1group.Title: Weekly donation reports during general election periods

P2para.Text: The responsible person in relation to a recognised third party must, in respect of each reporting period that falls within a general election period, prepare a report about substantial donations (“a weekly report”).
The reporting periods are—

P3para.Text: the period of 7 days beginning with the first day of the general election period,
each succeeding period of 7 days falling within the general election period, and
any final period of less than 7 days falling within that period.

P2para.Text: A “general election period” means the period—

P3para.Text: beginning with the day on which Parliament is dissolved for a parliamentary general election, and
ending with the date during a qualifying regulated period which is the date of the poll for that election.

P2para.Text: A weekly report must comply with the requirements of Schedule 11A.

A “substantial donation” means a relevant donation of a substantial value which is received by the recognised third party during the reporting period in respect of the relevant election or elections the poll or polls for which take place during the qualifying regulated period.
A relevant donation is “of a substantial value” if its value (as determined in accordance with paragraph 5 of Schedule 11) is more than £7,500.
A weekly report must be delivered to the Commission by the responsible person within the period of 7 days beginning with the end of the reporting period to which it relates.

The report must be accompanied by a declaration signed by the responsible person stating that, to the best of that person’s knowledge and belief, no substantial donations have been received by the recognised third party during the reporting period which are required to be recorded in the report in accordance with Schedule 11A and are not so recorded.
This section does not require the preparation of a weekly report in respect of a reporting period if no substantial donations are received by the recognised third party during that period.
In this section—

Para.Text: “qualifying regulated period” means a period in relation to which any limit is imposed by paragraph 3, 9, 10 or 11 of Schedule 10 (periods involving parliamentary general elections);
“relevant donation” has the same meaning as in Schedule 11.

P2para.Text: This section does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: a recognised third party which is a registered party other than a minor party, or
a recognised Gibraltar third party.

P2para.Text: The responsible person in relation to a recognised third party commits an offence if, without reasonable excuse, the responsible person—

P3para.Text: fails to deliver a quarterly or weekly report in accordance with section 95A(8) or 95B(7),
delivers a quarterly or weekly report to the Commission without the accompanying declaration required under section 95A(9) or 95B(8), or
delivers a quarterly or weekly report to the Commission which does not comply with the requirements of Schedule 11A.

P2para.Text: The responsible person in relation to a recognised third party commits an offence if the person knowingly or recklessly makes a false declaration under section 95A(9) or 95B(8).
The court may, on an application made by the Commission, order the forfeiture by a recognised third party of an amount equal to the value of a relevant donation where the court is satisfied that—

P1group.Title: Duty to provide membership audit certificate

P2para.Text: A trade union required to maintain a register of the names and addresses of its members by section 24 must send to the Certification Officer a membership audit certificate in relation to each reporting period.
In this section and in sections 24ZB to 24ZF, a “reporting period” means a period in relation to which the union is required by section 32 to send an annual return to the Certification Officer.

The union must send the membership audit certificate in relation to a reporting period to the Certification Officer at the same time as it sends to the Officer its annual return under section 32 in relation to that period.

In the case of a trade union required by section 24ZB to appoint an assurer in relation to a reporting period, the “membership audit certificate” in relation to that period is the certificate which the assurer is required to provide to the union in relation to that period pursuant to that appointment.
In any other case, the “membership audit certificate” in relation to a reporting period is a certificate which—

P3para.Text: must be signed by an officer of the trade union who is authorised to sign on its behalf,
must state the officer’s name, and
must state whether, to the best of the officer’s knowledge and belief, the union has complied with its duties under section 24(1) throughout the reporting period.

P2para.Text: A trade union must, at a person’s request, supply the person with a copy of its most recent membership audit certificate either free of charge or on payment of a reasonable charge.

P2para.Text: The Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 is amended as follows.
After section 24ZA (which is inserted by section 40), insert—

A trade union required to maintain a register of the names and addresses of its members by section 24 must, in relation to each reporting period, appoint a qualified independent person to be an assurer in relation to that period.
There is incorporated in the assurer’s appointment a duty which the assurer owes to the trade union—

P3para.Text: to provide to the union a membership audit certificate in relation to the reporting period which accords with the requirements of section 24ZD, and
to carry out such enquiries as the assurer considers necessary to enable the assurer to provide that certificate.

P2para.Text: A person is a “qualified independent person” if—

P3para.Text: the person either satisfies such conditions as may be specified for the purposes of this section by order of the Secretary of State or is specified by name in such an order, and
the trade union has no grounds for believing that—

P4para.Text: the person will carry out an assurer’s functions otherwise than competently, or
the person’s independence in relation to the union might reasonably be called into question.

P2para.Text: None of the following may act as an assurer—

P3para.Text: an officer or employee of the trade union or of any of its branches or sections;
a person who is a partner of, or in the employment of, or who employs, such an officer or employee.

P2para.Text: This section does not apply to a trade union in relation to a reporting period if the number of its members at the end of the preceding reporting period did not exceed 10,000.
Any order under this section is to be made by statutory instrument and is to be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

P1group.Title: Appointment and removal of an assurer

P2para.Text: The rules of every trade union to which section 24ZB applies must contain provision for the appointment and removal of an assurer.
But the following provisions have effect notwithstanding anything in the rules.
But the following provisions have effect notwithstanding anything in the rules.
An assurer must not be removed from office except by resolution passed at a general meeting of the members of the union or of delegates of its members.
A person duly appointed as an assurer in relation to a reporting period must be reappointed as assurer in relation to the following reporting period, unless—

P3para.Text: a resolution has been passed at a general meeting of the trade union appointing somebody else instead or providing expressly that the person is not to be re-appointed,
the person has given notice to the union in writing of the person’s unwillingness to be re-appointed,
the person is not qualified for the appointment in accordance with section 24ZB, or
the person has ceased to act as assurer by reason of incapacity.

P2para.Text: But a person need not automatically be re-appointed where—

P3para.Text: the person is retiring,
notice has been given of an intended resolution to appoint somebody else instead, and
that resolution cannot be proceeded with at the meeting because of the death or incapacity of the proposed replacement.

P1group.Title: Requirements of assurer’s membership audit certificate

P2para.Text: For the purposes of section 24ZB(2)(a) the requirements of a membership audit certificate in relation to a reporting period provided by an assurer are as follows.
The certificate must state the name of, and be signed by, the assurer.
The certificate must state—

P3para.Text: whether, in the assurer’s opinion, the trade union’s system for compiling and maintaining the register of the names and addresses of its members was satisfactory for the purposes of complying with the union’s duties under section 24(1) throughout the reporting period, and
whether, in the assurer’s opinion, the assurer has obtained the information and explanations which the assurer considers necessary for the performance of the assurer’s functions.

P2para.Text: If the certificate states that—

P3para.Text: in the assurer’s opinion, the trade union’s system for compiling and maintaining the register was not satisfactory for the purposes of complying with the union’s duties under section 24(1) throughout the reporting period, or
in the assurer’s opinion, the assurer has failed to obtain the information and explanations which the assurer considers necessary for the performance of the assurer’s functions,

P2para.Text: the certificate must state the assurer’s reasons for making that statement.
In the case of a failure to obtain information or explanations as described in subsection (4)(b), the certificate must also—

P3para.Text: provide a description of the information or explanations requested or required which have not been obtained, and
state whether the assurer required that information or those explanations from the union’s officers, or officers of any of its branches or sections, under section 24ZE.

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (2) to signature by the assurer is, where that office is held by a body corporate or partnership, to signature in the name of the body corporate or partnership by an individual authorised to sign on its behalf.
An assurer appointed by a trade union under section 24ZB—

P3para.Text: has a right of access at all reasonable times to the register of the names and addresses of the union’s members and to all other documents which the assurer considers may be relevant to whether the union has complied with any of the requirements of section 24(1), and

is entitled to require from the union’s officers, or the officers of any of its branches or sections, such information and explanations as the assurer considers necessary for the performance of the assurer’s functions.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) references to documents include information recorded in any form.

P1group.Title: Duty to inform the Certification Officer

P1para.Text: If an assurer provides a membership audit certificate in relation to a reporting period to a trade union which states that, in the assurer’s opinion—

P3para.Text: the union’s system for compiling and maintaining the register was not satisfactory for the purposes of complying with the union’s duties under section 24(1) throughout that period, or
the assurer has failed to obtain the information and explanations which the assurer considers necessary for the performance of the assurer’s functions,

P1para.Text: the assurer must send a copy of the certificate to the Certification Officer as soon as is reasonably practicable after it is provided to the union.

P2para.Text: The duty of confidentiality as respects the register is incorporated in an assurer’s appointment by a trade union under section 24ZB.
The duty of confidentiality as respects the register is a duty which the assurer owes to the union—

P3para.Text: not to disclose any name or address in the register of the names and addresses of the union’s members except in permitted circumstances, and
to take all reasonable steps to secure that there is no disclosure of any such name or address by another person except in permitted circumstances.

P2para.Text: The circumstances in which disclosure of a member’s name or address is permitted are—

P3para.Text: where the member consents,
where it is required or requested by the Certification Officer for the purposes of the discharge of any of the Officer’s functions,
where it is required for the purposes of the discharge of any of the functions of an inspector appointed by the Officer,
where it is required for the purposes of the discharge of any of the functions of the assurer, or
where it is required for the purposes of the investigation of crime or criminal proceedings.

P1group.Title: Power of Certification Officer to require production of documents etc

P2para.Text: If the Certification Officer thinks there is good reason to do so, the Officer—

P3para.Text: may give directions to a trade union, or a branch or section of a trade union, requiring it to produce such relevant documents as are specified in the directions;

may authorise a member of the Officer’s staff or any other person (“an authorised person”), on producing (if so required) evidence of that authority, to require a trade union, or a branch or section of a trade union, to produce immediately to the authorised person such relevant documents as that person specifies.

P2para.Text: “Relevant documents”, in relation to a trade union or a branch or section of a trade union, means—

P3para.Text: the register of the names and addresses of the trade union’s members, and
documents of any other description which the Certification Officer or authorised person considers may be relevant to whether the union has failed to comply with any of the
requirements of section 24(1) (duties regarding the register of members).

P2para.Text: Directions under subsection (1)(a) must specify the time and place at which the documents are to be produced.

Where the Certification Officer, or an authorised person, has power to require the production of documents by virtue of subsection (1), the Officer or authorised person has the like power to require production of those documents from any person who appears to the Officer or authorised person to be in possession of them.
The power under this section to require the production of documents includes the power—

P3para.Text: if the documents are produced—

P4para.Text: to take copies of them or extracts from them;
to require the person by whom they are produced to provide an explanation of any of them;
to require any person who is or has been an official or agent of the trade union to provide an explanation of any of them;

P3para.Text: if the documents are not produced, to require the person who was required to produce them to state, to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, where they are.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (5)(a)(iii), “agent” includes an assurer appointed by the trade union under section 24ZB.
For supplementary provision, see section 24ZK.
The Certification Officer may appoint one or more members of the Officer’s staff or other persons as an inspector or inspectors to—

P3para.Text: investigate whether a trade union has failed to comply with any of the requirements of section 24(1) (duties regarding the register of members), and
report to the Officer in such manner as the Officer may direct.

P2para.Text: The Certification Officer may only make such an appointment if it appears to the Officer that there are circumstances suggesting that the union has failed to comply with a requirement of section 24(1), 24ZA or 24ZB (duties etc relating to the register of members).

Where any person appears to the inspector or inspectors to be in possession of information relating to a matter considered by the inspector or inspectors to be relevant to the investigation, the inspector or inspectors may require the person—

P3para.Text: to produce to the inspector or inspectors any relevant documents relating to that matter,
to attend before the inspector or inspectors, and
otherwise to give the inspector or inspectors all assistance in connection with the investigation which the person is reasonably able to give.

P2para.Text: “Relevant documents” means—

P3para.Text: the register of the names and addresses of the trade union’s members, and
documents of any other description which the inspector or inspectors consider may be relevant to whether the union has failed to comply with any of the requirements of section 24(1).

P2para.Text: Where a person who is not a member of the Certification Officer’s staff is appointed as an inspector under this section, there is incorporated in the appointment the duty of confidentiality as respects the register of the names and addresses of the trade union’s members.
The duty of confidentiality as respects that register is a duty which the inspector owes to the Certification Officer—

P3para.Text: not to disclose any name or address in the register of the names and addresses of the union’s members except in permitted circumstances, and
to take all reasonable steps to secure that there is no disclosure of any such name or address by another person except in permitted circumstances.

P2para.Text: The circumstances in which disclosure of a member’s name or address is permitted are—

P3para.Text: where the member consents,
where it is required or requested by the Certification Officer for the purposes of the discharge of any of the Officer’s functions,
where it is required for the purposes of the discharge of any of the functions of the inspector or any other inspector appointed by the Officer,
where it is required for the purposes of the discharge of any of the functions of an assurer appointed under section 24ZB, or
where it is required for the purposes of the investigation of crime or criminal proceedings.

P2para.Text: For supplementary provision, see section 24ZK.
An inspector or inspectors appointed under section 24ZI—

P3para.Text: may make interim reports to the Certification Officer,
must make such reports if so directed by the Officer, and
on the conclusion of the investigation, must make a final report to the Officer.

P2para.Text: A report under subsection (1) must be in writing.
An inspector or inspectors—

P3para.Text: may at any time inform the Certification Officer of any matters coming to their knowledge as a result of the investigation, and
must do so if the Officer so directs.

P2para.Text: The Certification Officer may direct an inspector or inspectors—

P3para.Text: to take no further steps in the investigation, or
to take only such further steps as are specified in the direction.

P2para.Text: Where such a direction is made, the inspector or inspectors are not required under subsection (1)(c) to make a final report to the Certification Officer unless the Officer so directs.
Nothing in section 24ZH or 24ZI requires or authorises anyone to require—

P3para.Text: the disclosure by a person of information which the person would in an action in the court be entitled to refuse to disclose on grounds of legal professional privilege, or
the production by a person of a document which the person would in such an action be entitled to refuse to produce on such grounds.

P2para.Text: But a lawyer may be required under section 24ZH or 24ZI to disclose the name and address of the lawyer’s client.

A person is not excused from providing an explanation or making a statement in compliance with a requirement imposed under section 24ZH(5) or 24ZI(3) on the ground that to do so would tend to expose the person to proceedings for an offence.

But an explanation so provided or a statement so made may only be used in evidence against the person by whom it is provided or made on a prosecution for an offence where, in giving evidence, the person makes a statement inconsistent with it.
In this section and in sections 24ZH and 24ZI—

P3para.Text: references to documents include information recorded in any form, and
in relation to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, references to its production are to the production of a copy of the information in legible form.

P1group.Title: Enforcement of sections 24 to 24ZC by Certification Officer

P2para.Text: Where the Certification Officer is satisfied that a trade union has failed to comply with any of the requirements of section 24, 24ZA, 24ZB or 24ZC (duties etc relating to the register of members), the Officer may make a declaration to that effect.
Before making such a declaration, the Certification Officer—

P3para.Text: may make such enquiries as the Officer thinks fit,
must give the union an opportunity to make written representations, and
may give the union an opportunity to make oral representations.

P2para.Text: If the Certification Officer makes a declaration it must specify the provisions with which the union has failed to comply.
Where the Certification Officer makes a declaration and is satisfied—

P3para.Text: that steps have been taken by the union with a view to remedying the declared failure or securing that a failure of the same or any similar kind does not occur in future, or
that the union has agreed to take such steps,

P2para.Text: the Officer must specify those steps in the declaration.
Where a declaration is made, the Certification Officer must give reasons in writing for making the declaration.
Where a declaration is made, the Certification Officer must also make an enforcement order unless the Officer considers that to do so would be inappropriate.
An “enforcement order” is an order imposing on the union one or both of the following requirements—

P3para.Text: to take such steps to remedy the declared failure, within such period, as may be specified in the order;
to abstain from such acts as may be so specified with a view to securing that a failure of the same or a similar kind does not occur in future.

P2para.Text: Where, having given the union an opportunity to make written representations under subsection (2)(b), the Certification Officer determines not to make a declaration under subsection (1), the Officer must give the union notice in writing of that determination.

Where the Certification Officer requests a person to provide information to the Officer in connection with enquiries under this section, the Officer must specify the date by which that information is to be provided.

Where the information is not provided by the specified date, the Certification Officer must proceed with determining whether to make a declaration under subsection (1) unless the Officer considers that it would be inappropriate to do so.
A declaration made by the Certification Officer under this section may be relied on as if it were a declaration made by the court.
An enforcement order made by the Certification Officer under this section may be enforced in the same way as an order of the court.

Where an enforcement order has been made, a person who is a member of the union and was a member at the time it was made is entitled to enforce obedience to the order as if the order had been made on an application by that person.

P1group.Title: Enforcement of sections 24ZH and 24ZI by Certification Officer

P2para.Text: Where the Certification Officer is satisfied that a trade union or any other person has failed to comply with any requirement imposed under—

P3para.Text: section 24ZH (power of Certification Officer to require production of documents etc), or
section 24ZI (investigations by inspectors),

P2para.Text: the Officer may make an order requiring the trade union or person to comply with the requirement.
Before making such an order, the Certification Officer must give the trade union or person an opportunity to be heard.
In the case of a failure to comply with a requirement imposed under section 24ZH or 24ZI to produce a document, the Certification Officer may make an order only if the Officer is satisfied that—

P3para.Text: the document is in the possession of the union or person, and
it is reasonably practicable for the union or person to comply with the requirement.

P2para.Text: In the case of a failure to comply with any other requirement imposed under section 24ZH or 24ZI, the Certification Officer may make an order only if the Officer is satisfied that it is reasonably practicable for the union or person to comply with the requirement.
The order must specify—

P3para.Text: the requirement with which the trade union or person has failed to comply, and
the date by which the trade union or person must comply.

P2para.Text: An order made by the Certification Officer under this section may be enforced in the same way as an order of the court.

TitleBlock.Title: Carrying on the business of consultant lobbying

P2para.Text: A person does not, by reason of making a communication, carry on the business of consultant lobbying if—

P3para.Text: the person carries on a business which consists mainly of non-lobbying activities, and
the making of the communication is incidental to the carrying on of those activities.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1) “non-lobbying activities” are activities other than making, on behalf of another person or persons, communications which—

P3para.Text: relate to any of the matters mentioned in section 2(3)(a) to (d), and
are made to any of the persons within sub-paragraph (3).

P2para.Text: The persons are—

P3para.Text: members of, and office-holders in, government, and
officials and members of staff of government.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this paragraph, “government” includes—

P3para.Text: Her Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom,
the Scottish Administration,
the Welsh Assembly Government,
the First Minister, the deputy First Minister, the Northern Ireland Ministers and any Northern Ireland department,
the Government of any sovereign Power other than the United Kingdom,
local government in any part of the United Kingdom, and
any institution of the European Union;

P2para.Text: (and the references to “the government” in section 2(3)(a) to (d) as applied by sub-paragraph (2)(a) are to be read accordingly).

P1para.Text: A person does not carry on the business of consultant lobbying if—

P3para.Text: the person acts generally as a representative of persons of a particular class or description,
the income of the person derives wholly or mainly from persons of that class or description, and
the making of communications within section 2(3) on behalf of those persons is no more than an incidental part of that general activity.

P2para.Text: A person who, as an official or member of staff of—

P3para.Text: a sovereign Power other than the United Kingdom, or the Government of such a Power, or
an international organisation,

P2para.Text: makes communications within section 2(3) on its behalf does not, by reason of those communications, carry on the business of consultant lobbying.

An “international organisation” is any organisation which, for the purposes of section 1 of the International Organisations Act 1968, is declared to be (or is treated as being) an organisation of which—

P3para.Text: the United Kingdom, or Her Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom, and
at least one other sovereign Power, or the Government of such a Power,

P2para.Text: are members.
Regulations may specify other organisations which are to be “international organisations” for the purposes of this paragraph.

P1para.Text: An individual does not carry on the business of consultant lobbying by reason of making communications as an employee in the course of a business carried on by the individual’s employer.

Part.Title: Meaning of terms used in section 2(1)

P2para.Text: “Payment” includes payment of any kind.
But “payment” does not include any sums payable to a member of either House of Parliament—

P3para.Text: under section 4 or 5 of the Parliamentary Standards Act 2009 (MPs’ salaries and allowances),
pursuant to a resolution or a combination of resolutions of the House of Lords relating to expenses and allowances for its members, or
otherwise out of money provided by Parliament or out of the Consolidated Fund (whether or not in respect of that membership).

P2para.Text: Communications may be made “in return for payment” whether the payment is made directly or indirectly.
In particular, it does not matter—

P3para.Text: whether the person or persons making the payments is or are the person or persons on behalf of whom the communications are made, or
whether a particular payment relates to any particular communication or communications.

P2para.Text: But a communication is not made “in return for payment” if—

P3para.Text: a person makes the communication on behalf of persons of a particular class or description,
the income of the person making the communication derives wholly or mainly from persons who are not of that class or description, and
the person does not receive payment, from persons of that class or description, in return for making that communication.

P2para.Text: If the person making the communication is an employee, the references in sub-paragraph (1)(b) and (c) to the person are to be read as references to the person’s employer.

P1para.Text: References in this Part of this Act to receiving payment to engage in lobbying are to be read in accordance with paragraphs 5 to 7.
A communication is not within section 2(3) if it is required to be made by or under any statutory provision or other rule of law.

P2para.Text: Where an individual (“A”) makes a communication in the course of a business carried on by another person (“B”), the communication is to be regarded as being made by B as well as by A.
Where A is an employee of B, then (whether or not the communication is made on behalf of a third party) A is not to be regarded as making the communication on behalf of B.
The positions mentioned in section 2(5) are—

P3para.Text: Cabinet Secretary;
Chief Executive of Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs;
Chief Medical Officer;
Director of Public Prosecutions;
First Parliamentary Counsel;
Government Chief Scientific Adviser;
Head of the Civil Service;
Prime Minister’s Adviser for Europe and Global Issues.

P2para.Text: Regulations may amend sub-paragraph (1) by adding or removing a position.

P1para.Text: The Registrar is a corporation sole.
The Registrar exercises the functions of that office on behalf of the Crown.

P2para.Text: The Registrar is to be appointed by the Minister.
The Registrar holds office in accordance with the terms and conditions of that appointment; but this is subject to sub-paragraphs (3) to (6).
The term of office for which the Registrar is appointed must not be more than 4 years.
A person may be appointed for a second or third term; but the term for which a person is re-appointed must not be more than 3 years.
The Registrar may resign by giving written notice to the Minister.
The Minister may dismiss the Registrar if the Minister is satisfied that the Registrar is unable, unwilling or unfit to perform the functions of the office.
A person is ineligible for appointment as the Registrar if, at any time in the previous 5 years, the person—

P3para.Text: was a Minister of the Crown or a permanent secretary, or
carried on the business of consultant lobbying or was an employee of a person who carried on that business.

P2para.Text: “Minister of the Crown” and “permanent secretary” have the meaning given by section 2(5).

P1para.Text: A defect in the Registrar’s appointment does not affect the validity of anything done by the Registrar.
Service as the Registrar is not service in the civil service of the State.

P2para.Text: The Registrar may make arrangements for sums in respect of the following to be paid to or in respect of the person holding office as the Registrar—

P3para.Text: remuneration;
allowances;
pension.

P2para.Text: The sums paid under sub-paragraph (1) are to be determined by the Minister.
The Registrar may make arrangements with the Minister or other persons—

P3para.Text: for staff to be seconded to the Registrar;
for accommodation or services to be provided to the Registrar.

P2para.Text: The payments that may be made under arrangements under sub-paragraph (1)(a) include payments to the staff in addition to, or instead of, payments to the person with whom the arrangements are made.
The Registrar must keep proper accounts and proper records in relation to the accounts.
The Registrar must prepare a statement of accounts in respect of each financial year.
The Registrar must send a copy of the statement, within a period specified by the Minister, to the Comptroller and Auditor General.
After the Registrar has sent a copy of a statement of accounts to the Comptroller and Auditor General, the Comptroller and Auditor General must—

P3para.Text: examine, certify and report on the statement, and
arrange for a copy of the certified statement and the report to be laid before Parliament as soon as possible.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “financial year” means—

P3para.Text: the period beginning on the day on which section 3 comes into force and ending on the following 31 March, and
each successive period of 12 months.

P2para.Text: The Minister may make grants or loans to the Registrar.
The grants or loans may be subject to conditions (including conditions as to repayment with or without interest).
